Answer to the question: "Can stress kill you?", yes.   I'm a retired neuropsychiatrist and have studied this question for 40yrs.   My conclusion: "stress" is actually population density stress, which is pretty well demonstrated in the comments for this neat little video.   We are the descendants of a world-wide population of 6 million hunter-gatherers, and only expanded to 7.4 billion because of the agricultural and industrial revolutions.  However, this expansion came at the price so well demonstrated by the mostly serious comments on this piece.   If you're interested in the details, Google "Stress R Us" for the free PDF.  If you care about the health and well-being of your off-spring and the planet, limit your family size to one-child, which will reduce our world-wide population to 2.5 billion by 2100.  Best wishes!

On the serious note though, I think that it's all fine as long as it's a moderate stress and as long as we regularly take a break and relax. Much like physical activity, two much of working out can cause dizziness, hyperventilation or even injuries, but it's all cool as long as you give yourself some time to recover.

So the moral of the story - we humans aren't used to have a bunch of stressors running in the background constantly, we are designed to have one or two stressful experiences happening only here and there and a lot of breaks and peaceful times in between.
So while we wait for "evolution to do it's thing" (which would take 1000s of years if at all), we might as well want to update our rusty, messed up and greedy system, especially the one regarding the division of labor.

There main job is to follow and mirror the emotional responses of others so we can understand our world better (in a way to understand what others are thinking).
